bestBHT.bht: The Vine contains both fruitful and unfruitful branches, and the Father removes the unfruitful ones, while pruning and cleansing the fruitful ones. The disciples of Christ can either be spiritually fruitful or not, depending on their true connection to Him. The process of pruning and cleansing may be painful, but it is necessary and beneficial, allowing the fruitful branches to bear even more fruit. This emphasizes the importance of remaining spiritually connected to Christ and allowing Him to purify us so that we may bear fruit and serve Him more effectively.

Henry Alford: The Vine contains fruitful and unfruitful branches.
Every such unfruitful branch the Father pulls off and casts away.
Every one that beareth fruit He prunes, by cleansing it of its worthless parts, and shortening its rank growth, that it may ripen and enlarge its fruit better.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The disciples of Christ may be spiritually fruitful or the reverse, according as they are vitally and spiritually connected with Christ, or but externally and mechanically attached to Him.
The fruitless He 'taketh away'; the fruitful He 'purgeth' (cleanseth, pruneth)—stripping it, as the husbandman does, of what is rank, 'that it may bring forth more fruit'.
A process often painful, but no less needful and beneficial than in the natural husbandry.
Albert Barnes: Jesus here says that he sustains the same relation to his disciples that a parent stalk does to the branches; but this does not denote any physical or incomprehensible union.
He takes away that which hindered their usefulness; teaches them; quickens them; revives them; makes them more pure in motive and in life.
So God often takes away the property of his people, their children, or other idols. He removes the objects which bind their affections, and which render them inactive.
Marvin Vincent: Branch [κλημα] . Occurring only in this chapter. Both this and kladov, branch (see on Matthew 24:32; Mark 11:8) are derived from klaw, to break. The word emphasizes the ideas of tenderness and flexibility.
John Calvin: Christ intends by these words to awaken anxious inquiry, by declaring that all the branches which shall be unfruitful will be cut off from the vine.
Believers need incessant culture that they may be prevented from degenerating; and that they produce nothing good, unless God continually apply his hand.
He shows what ought to be the progress of believers in the course of true religion.
Philip Schaff: Any branch of the vine that is found, and as soon as it is found, to be not fruit-bearing is cut off.
The object of the Father is the inward, spiritual, cleansing of His children, in contrast with the outward purifications of Israel.
The attaining of this perfection is, however, a gradual process, and hence the words 'that it may bear more fruit'.
Archibald T. Robertson: The fruitless (not bearing fruit, μη φερον καρπον) the vine-dresser 'takes away' (αιρε) or prunes away. Probably (Bernard) Jesus here refers to Judas.
Cleanseth (καθαιρε). Present active indicative of old verb καθαιρω (clean) as in verse John 15:3, only use in N.T., common in the inscriptions for ceremonial cleansing.

That it may bear more fruit (ινα καρπον πλειονα φερη). Purpose clause with ινα and present active subjunctive of φερω, 'that it may keep on bearing more fruit' (more and more). A good test for modern Christians and church members.
John Gill: There are two sorts of branches in Christ the vine; the one sort are such who have only an historical faith in him, believe but for a time, and are removed...
These branches are unfruitful ones; what fruit they seemed to have, withers away, and proves not to be genuine fruit...
These are the other sort of branches, who are truly and savingly in Christ; such as are rooted in him; to whom he is the green fir tree, from whom all their fruit is found...
John Wesley: Every one that beareth fruit, he purifieth...So purity and fruitfulness help each other.
For this is one of the noblest rewards God can bestow on former acts of obedience, to make us yet more holy.
Fit for farther and more eminent service.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Vine contains both fruitful and unfruitful branches, and the Father removes the unfruitful ones, while pruning and cleansing the fruitful ones. The disciples of Christ can either be spiritually fruitful or not, depending on their true connection to Him. The process of pruning and cleansing may be painful, but it is necessary and beneficial, allowing the fruitful branches to bear even more fruit. This emphasizes the importance of remaining spiritually connected to Christ and allowing Him to purify us so that we may bear fruit and serve Him more effectively.

The Vine contains fruitful and unfruitful branches. Every such unfruitful branch the Father pulls off and casts away. Every one that beareth fruit He prunes, by cleansing it and shortening its growth, that it may ripen and enlarge its fruit better. The disciples of Christ may be spiritually fruitful or the reverse, according as they are vitally and spiritually connected with Him, or externally and mechanically attached to Him. The fruitless He 'taketh away'; the fruitful He 'purgeth'—stripping it of what is rank, 'that it may bring forth more fruit'.

The fruitful and unfruitful branches are found in the Vine. The Father removes the unfruitful ones while pruning and cleansing the fruitful ones to enhance their growth and productivity. The disciples' spiritual fruitfulness depends on their vital connection with Christ. The process of pruning and cleansing can be painful but is necessary and beneficial. In remaining connected and allowing the Father to purify us, we can bear more fruit and serve Him more effectively.

The Vine consists of fruitful and unfruitful branches, with the Father removing the unfruitful ones. He prunes and cleanses the fruitful branches, stripping them of what is rank, so that they may bring forth more fruit. The disciples' fruitfulness is determined by their vital spiritual connection to Christ, rather than mere external attachment. Though the process may be painful, it is necessary and beneficial, allowing the branches to bear more fruit. This highlights the importance of remaining connected to Christ and being purified in order to serve Him more effectively.

The Vine has fruitful and unfruitful branches. The Father removes the unfruitful ones, while pruning and cleansing the fruitful branches to increase their fruitfulness. The disciples' spiritual productivity is dependent on their vital connection with Christ. The process of pruning and cleansing may be painful but is necessary and beneficial, enabling the branches to bear more fruit. This emphasizes the significance of maintaining a deep connection with Christ and allowing Him to purify us, resulting in greater effectiveness in serving Him.
